p.text: “Identification evidence” is defined in the Dictionary.
This Part applies only in a criminal proceeding.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [51,025] s 114 Exclusion of visual identification evidence

p.text: In this section:
means identification evidence relating to an identification based wholly or partly on what a person saw but does not include picture identification evidence.
Visual identification evidence adduced by the prosecutor is not admissible unless:
an identification parade that included the defendant was held before the identification was made, or
it would not have been reasonable to have held such a parade, or
the defendant refused to take part in such a parade,
and the identification was made without the person who made it having been intentionally influenced to identify the defendant.
Without limiting the matters that may be taken into account by the court in determining whether it was reasonable to hold an identification parade, it is to take into account:
the kind of offence, and the gravity of the offence, concerned, and
the importance of the evidence, and
the practicality of holding an identification parade having regard, among other things:
if the defendant failed to cooperate in the conduct of the parade — to the manner and extent of, and the reason (if any) for, the failure, and
in any case — to whether the identification was made at or about the time of the commission of the offence, and
the appropriateness of holding an identification parade having regard, among other things, to the relationship (if any) between the defendant and the person who made the identification.
It is presumed that it would not have been reasonable to have held an identification parade if it would have been unfair to the defendant for such a parade to have been held.
If:

the defendant refused to take part in an identification parade unless an Australian legal practitioner or legal counsel acting for the defendant, or another person chosen by the defendant, was present while it was being held, and

there were, at the time when the parade was to have been conducted, reasonable grounds to believe that it was not reasonably practicable for such an Australian legal practitioner or legal counsel or person to be present, it is presumed that it would not have been reasonable to have held an identification parade at that time.
[subs (5) am Act No 46 of 2007 s 3 and Sch 1[53], effective 1 January 2009]

In determining whether it was reasonable to have held an identification parade, the court is not to take into account the availability of pictures or photographs that could be used in making identifications.
See Sch 2 Pt 2 cl 9 of the Evidence Act 1995, reproduced at [51,865] .
ALRC 26 vol 1 paras 830–832, 833
ALRC 38 paras 185–187
Legislation cited in [51,025.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 114(2), s 114(2)(b), s 79.

The provisions for identification parades are consistent with a number of authorities that require such a parade except in special circumstances: R v Bouquet [1962] NSWR 1034; [1962] SR (NSW) 563; (1961) 79 WN (NSW) 423 .

The concept of “visual identification evidence” is not limited to “in court” evidence. It includes any evidence that identifies the defendant as the person involved in the relevant offence. The consequence of this is that the question of the reasonableness of holding an identification parade is to be determined in the light of the circumstances when the witness first identified the defendant. It is not to be assessed by reference to the reasonableness of such a parade before the witness gives evidence of identification in the proceedings: Walford v Director of Public Prosecutions (NSW) [2012] NSWCA 290; BC201207093 disapproving R v Taylor (2008) 2 ACTLR 216; [2008] ACTSC 52; BC200804439 ; see also R v D (2008) 2 ACTLR 225; 220 FLR 169; [2008] ACTSC 82; BC200807914 .

Once the provisions of the section are found to apply, the evidence is not to be admitted unless it falls within one of the three exceptions set out in s 114(2) : R v Thomason (1999) 139 ACTR 21; [1999] ACTSC 112; BC9907150 . However, it is to be borne in mind that the touchstone of s 114(2)(b) is whether it would not have been "reasonable" to have held an identification parade, not whether it would have been possible to have done so: R v Leroy [2000] NSWCCA 302; BC200004875 .

If an identification parade is to take place it is essential that (inter alia) those taking part in it are of the same age, height and general appearance: R v Fisher [2001] NSWCCA 380; BC200106181 . The provisions that allow the admission of other identification evidence if an accused refuses to take part in an identification parade are also consistent with the common law: R v Haidley (1984) 10 A Crim R 1; [1984] VR 229 ; R v Smith [1984] 1 NSWLR 462; (1984) 12 A Crim R 439 ; Shannon v R (1987) 47 SASR 347; 29 A Crim R 434 .

As to the directions to be given by a trial judge to a jury when an accused refuses to take part in an identification parade see McCarthy & Ryan v R (1993) 71 A Crim R 395 . See also the notes to s 79 at [50,700.20] above.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [51,030] s 115 Exclusion of evidence of identification by pictures

leg:heading.title: Exclusion of evidence of identification by pictures

p.text: In this section:
means identification evidence relating to an identification made wholly or partly by the person who made the identification examining pictures kept for the use of police officers.
Picture identification evidence adduced by the prosecutor is not admissible if the pictures examined suggest that they are pictures of persons in police custody.
Subject to subsection (4) , picture identification evidence adduced by the prosecutor is not admissible if:
when the pictures were examined, the defendant was in the custody of a police officer of the police force investigating the commission of the offence with which the defendant has been charged, and
the picture of the defendant that was examined was made before the defendant was taken into that police custody.
Subsection (3) does not apply if:
the defendant's appearance had changed significantly between the time when the offence was committed and the time when the defendant was taken into that custody, or
it was not reasonably practicable to make a picture of the defendant after the defendant was taken into that custody.

Picture identification evidence adduced by the prosecutor is not admissible if, when the pictures were examined, the defendant was in the custody of a police officer of the police force investigating the commission of the offence with which the defendant has been charged, unless:
the defendant refused to take part in an identification parade, or
the defendant's appearance had changed significantly between the time when the offence was committed and the time when the defendant was taken into that custody, or
it would not have been reasonable to have held an identification parade that included the defendant.
Sections 114(3) , (4) , (5) and (6) apply in determining, for the purposes of subsection (5)(c) of this section, whether it would have been reasonable to have held an identification parade.
If picture identification evidence adduced by the prosecutor is admitted into evidence, the judge must, on the request of the defendant:
if the picture of the defendant was made after the defendant was taken into that custody — inform the jury that the picture was made after the defendant was taken into that custody, or
otherwise — warn the jury that they must not assume that the defendant has a criminal record or has previously been charged with an offence.
Sections 116 (Directions to jury) and 165 (Unreliable evidence) also deal with warnings about identification evidence.
This section does not render inadmissible picture identification evidence adduced by the prosecutor that contradicts or qualifies picture identification evidence adduced by the defendant.
This section applies in addition to section 114 .
In this section:
a reference to a picture includes a reference to a photograph, and
a reference to making a picture includes a reference to taking a photograph.
See Sch 2 Pt 2 cl 9 of the Evidence Act 1995, reproduced at [51,865] .
ALRC 38 paras 188—190
Legislation cited in [51,030.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 115.

The provisions of s 115 reflect a number of authorities in which the dangers of identification evidence have been discussed. Whilst at common law a police officer is at liberty to show photographs to persons for the purposes of identification of an accused, the practice of showing photographs of the accused to witnesses who are to be called to give identification evidence for the prosecution has not been judicially approved: R v Dwyer [1925] 2 KB 799; Palmer v R [1981] 1 NSWLR 209; (1981) 1 A Crim R 458. As to identification from photographs generally and the dangers posed by such evidence see Alexander v R (1981) 145 CLR 395; 34 ALR 289; BC8100066 and R v Aziz [1982] 2 NSWLR 322.

The section is primarily concerned with pictures kept for the use of police officers (that is, those colloquially known as “mug shots”) as opposed to (inter alia) bank security photographs or video tapes: see R v Hennessy [2001] NSWCCA 36; BC200100544 ; R v McDonald [2001] NSWCCA 363; BC200105542 . For the purposes of the application of the section, the term “in the custody of a police officer” should be given its normal meaning, namely that under the physical restraint of a police officer: R v McKellar [2000] NSWCCA 523; BC200007827 .

Specific considerations arise in circumstances where a witness, who has previously known a person well enough to recognise them on sight, looks at a photograph of that person (not being a picture of the type referred to in s 115) and then seeks to give evidence about what that photograph shows. Evidence from police officers to the effect that they have had previous dealings with the person in a particular photograph and can recognise them as the accused has been held by the High Court to be irrelevant and inadmissible: Smith v R (2001) 206 CLR 650; 181 ALR 354; 75 ALJR 1398; [2001] HCA 50; BC200104729 ; c/f R v Hennessy [2001] NSWCCA 36; BC200100544 . There may, however, be occasions when evidence of that kind could be relevant, such as those occasions on which a witness deposes to having identified someone from a photograph and the identity of the person is established in some other way: Smith v R (above) citing Alexander v R (1981) 145 CLR 395; 34 ALR 289; BC8100066 .
If identification evidence has been admitted, the judge is to inform the jury:
that there is a special need for caution before accepting identification evidence, and
of the reasons for that need for caution, both generally and in the circumstances of the case.
It is not necessary that a particular form of words be used in so informing the jury.
ALRC 26 vol 1 para 841
ALRC 38 para 191

level.toc-caption: [51,035.10] Warning about the unreliability of identification evidence

p.text: Legislation cited in [51,035.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 165.

heading.title: Warning about the unreliability of identification evidence

p.text: The position at common law was that a trial judge was required to give a cogent and effective warning to the jury of the possible unreliability of the identification evidence and warn the jury of the need for caution in deciding whether or not to accept the evidence: Domican v R (1992) 173 CLR 555; 106 ALR 203; BC9202665 ; Kelleher v R (1974) 131 CLR 534; 4 ALR 450 ; Davies v R (1937) 57 CLR 170 at 182; [1937] VLR 205 ; R v Pitkin (1995) 130 ALR 35; 69 ALJR 612 (evidence of similarity of appearance is not sufficient to justify conviction): see also s 165 of the Evidence Act and R v Clarke (1997) 97 A Crim R 414; BC9705745 ; R v Rose (2002) 55 NSWLR 701; [2002] NSWCCA 455; BC200206847 ; R v Inamata (2003) 137 A Crim R 510; [2003] NSWCCA 19; BC200300320 . There is now some support for the proposition that the warning which is required to be given by virtue of the operation of ss 116 and 165 of the Act corresponds entirely with the position at common law: R v Eldridge [2002] NSWCCA 205 at [44]; BC200202865 .

The terms of s 116 require the trial judge to address specifically all of the elements of the section: R v Nguyen [2000] NSWCCA 285; BC200004873 . Although no particular formulation of words is required, the warning must be sufficient to convey the special nature of the need for caution in relation to identification evidence: R v Clarke (above); R v Bruno (NSWCCA, 7 July 1997, unreported, BC9702877); R v Smith [2000] NSWCCA 468; BC200007410 .
Legislation cited in [51,035.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Evidence Act 1995 s 135, s 137, s 165.

There is no threshold limitation on the admissibility of voiced identification evidence: R v Adler (2000) 116 A Crim R 38; BC200005657; [2000] NSWCA 357 distinguishing R v Smith [1984] 1 NSWLR 462; (1984) 12 A Crim R 439 . However, s 165 requires a judge to warn a jury about the possible unreliability of the evidence, and it may be excluded in the exercise of the discretions conferred by s 135 and s 137 of the Evidence Act.
